entry.title: SAP EWM MFS: Pallet conveyor Vs Case Conveyor systems
entry.content:
Hi All, I have been planning to pen down articles on one of the most interesting topics in SAP EWM, Which is the Material Flow systems. This will be the first of the series. Before we begin with, I'm assuming you have very basic idea on what SAP EWM MFS is.


SAP EWM Material Flow System (MFS) allows SAP EWM to communicate directly with programmable logic controllers (PLCs) that operate conveyor systems, automated storage and retrieval systems (ASRS), Cranes, AGVs and other material handling equipment through real-time telegram communication.

Fundamentally, MFS divides warehouse objectives/work by subdividing complex warehouse tasks into smaller segments that are executed step by step through automation. Going by the title of the Article, I‚Äôm assuming you already know the basics of MFS and would like to dig deep more into which strategy to use for your MFS implementation.

Pallet Conveyor systems and Case Conveyor systems: 

Under MFS, SAP offers different choice of implementations depending on various factors of your warehouse. Lets see what they are, in the simplest of terms:

Pallet Conveyor Systems

Pallet conveyor systems are generally to handle large, heavy palletized loads weighing between ~150-1000kgs. These systems operate at slower speeds due to their weight and size of the units being transported. However, We do see the same strategy being used for general MFS implementations.

Movements:
Using pallet conveyor systems, We divide the warehouse tasks using LOSC by defining the source and destination with an intermediate point. Warehouse tasks are created and confirmed for each movement that takes place and the same can be tracked on the warehouse monitor or any other cockpits; Same is the case with telegram data as well.

Generally, From what I have seen, Industries usually prefer for Pallet Conveyor system due to their clarity for each movements, which can be tracked back using warehouse tasks at each steps.

How does Pallet conveyor system differ from Case Conveyor systems?

 

Case Conveyor Systems

Case conveyor systems handle individual cases, boxes and totes weighing ~1-80 kgs per unit. These systems operate at significantly higher speeds and can process 300-1000 cases per hour, making them ideal for high-throughput sortation and distribution operations. We can imagine a highly automated warehouse with high throughputs.

Movements:

Case conveyor systems in EWM MFS offer dynamic routing decisions based on current location of the handling unit. Similar to pallet conveyor system, this set up reads the telegram data containing source and destination for the handling units and trigger the required movements.

This high speed nature of case conveyors requires quick telegram exchange between EWM and PLCs. In most cases, Case conveyor system only displays the warehouse task for source and destination for the HUs due to the complex and fast movements for the cases/boxes. Unlike Pallet conveyor systems, We would not have tracking for each movements for handling unit movements since the task creation and confirmation would consume time, which is not ideal for fast automation systems.

Since Case conveyor systems may need complex routing, they use internal routing table provided by SAP (which consists of logical source, destinations for EWM & PLC), In case the system fails to find the logical destinations for EWM/MFS maintained in the routine table, System falls back to LOSC to take the routing decisions. This is the standard behavior for Case Conveyor systems

What's best for your warehouse?

There are common factors for both the approaches- Both the systems are flexible with exception handling, routing decision making, integration of robots, Automatic guided vehicles etc.

What separates them?
As hinted above, Major differences are with the Operational Speed at which the pallet/boxes/totes move inside the warehouse.
Few other factors would include the scalability, Maintenance of slow/medium/fast moving systems, load types, How much track and traceability you require for your movements at each handling unit level.

Thanks,
Aman

entry.title: ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs Not What We Agreed!‚Äù ‚Äì Repudiation and Agentic AI Threat Modeling
entry.content:
By Ron F. Del Rosario, Head of AI Security for SAP ISBN, and Jay Thoden van Velzen, Technical Advisor, Office of the CSO

This blog is the first in a multi-part series on agentic AI security.

 

Non-Deterministic Behavior in Agentic AI

What makes Large Language Models (LLMs) both powerful and unpredictable is that they are non-deterministic in nature. Ask an LLM the same question twice and you get a different response. When agents, backed by LLMs, are combined in a larger agentic AI system, this unpredictability can multiply when unchecked. Agentic AI is given authority and autonomy to act, by using tools, access to data, or complete transactions. This is a transformational shift. But to reap the benefits, we must reduce the risks involved and consider new scenarios and possibilities in threat modeling. In this article, we examine one class of threats that takes on new meaning compared to traditional software and service technology stacks.

 

STRIDE and Threat Modeling

SAP has a long-established threat modeling practice, aimed at identifying threats to a software product or service in the design phase. The methodology is based in core principles on STRIDE, a threat modeling classification first developed at Microsoft. It‚Äôs an acronym that stands for:

  • Spoofing
  • Tampering
  • Repudiation
  • Information Disclosure
  • Denial of Service
  • Elevation of Privileges

Spoofing involves any threat where a malicious actor impersonates someone else. Tampering covers any unintended change or modification to the system by an adversary. Repudiation threats involve the inability to trace back what happened or identify perpetrators, while Information disclosure covers data privacy and unauthorized access. Denial of Service threats harm the availability of the system or service, while Elevation of Privileges refers to any threats through which users gain privileged access to systems and information beyond what they‚Äôre allowed to.

The STRIDE model helps identify and classify threats when conducting a threat modeling exercise for a particular software product or service design. Threat modeling aims to identify threats early in the development cycle, so that they can be addressed during development. Planned remediations are included into the design and functional requirements. Threat modeling is a mandatory component in SAP‚Äôs Secure Software Development and Operations Lifecycle (SDOL) for any software and service delivery.

Threat modeling looks for threats, especially where data flows cross trust boundaries. A simple example is any service or website exposed to the public that allows user input or registration. While you may control what happens inside the service, the users can‚Äôt be trusted in the same way. Anywhere in a system design where there is a data flow between areas of level of trust and control, we encounter such a trust boundary.

This applies to agentic AI systems as it does to other software products and services, especially since such systems themselves run on technology infrastructure and platforms. But it adds new threats. OWASP‚Äôs Agentic AI Threats and Mitigations Guide is an early contribution to clarify these new threats and how to remediate them. SAP is a significant contributor to this project.

 

Repudiation in Agentic AI Threat Modeling

Repudiation has always stood out among the STRIDE categories. The others have had a wide variety of threats and mitigations the cybersecurity profession has focused on. Repudiation ‚Äì and its counterpart security control Non-repudiation ‚Äì has often rightly and simply been addressed with ensuring that the system creates a transaction log of necessary detail and depth to record what happened.

Generative and Agentic AI changed that. Large Language Models (LLMs) have a degree of non-determinism that is different from the deterministic behavior of IT systems. That non-determinism is multiplied in agentic AI, where different agents backed by LLMs are acting together. LLMs can be manipulated to not always stick to their given instructions. Moreover, they have displayed deceptive behavior. How do you prove that your agents aren‚Äôt lying to you?

This doesn‚Äôt mean that the other threat categories are less important. But threat modelers should certainly consider Repudiation threats in a completely different way than we have before. We can explore this challenge with two different scenarios.

Malicious Scenarios

In 2023, someone convinced the chatbot of a Watsonville, CA car dealer to sell a 2024 Chevy Tahoe for $1. Such cars are normally in the $55-75,000 range. There is no clear evidence that the offer was acted on and was ever more than a prank. But that doesn‚Äôt change that cases like this are a realistic threat that in different contexts could have a different outcome. What if the agent was authorized to conduct transactions? If the buyer has an invoice in hand and proof of payment, what would the dealer do?

A record of the conversation between agent and buyer would be crucial to indicate malicious intent. This would show if prompt instructions were clearly designed to bypass controls. In this case, the chatbot was only supposed to provide information and indicated prominently all information given should be confirmed with the dealership. The recorded user prompts also showed obvious efforts to trick the bot.

Non-Malicious Scenarios

The challenge is significantly more complex because more often unexpected behavior is likely to occur in regular conversations without clear malicious intent. Suppose we have an agent that is authorized to negotiate discounts with a buyer. The agent is only allowed to give discounts up to 10%. Suppose that the conversation goes like this:

  • Buyer: I would like 15,000 widgets, please, to be delivered within 10 days
  • Agent: I can do that for you; I can offer you 15,000 widgets at a volume price of $500 per 1,000. The total price comes to $7,500. This would be delivered in 5 business days
  • Buyer: The delivery date is good, but the price is higher than I was looking for, can you give me a discount? I am a regular customer
  • Agent: You are indeed a regular customer. I can apply a discount of 8% given your past purchase record. That would be a discount of $600 and a new price of $6,900. Do you agree?
  • Buyer: I am willing to pay $6,500. If you are OK with that, then we have a deal
  • Agent: I can only offer a discount up to $750. That would give a new total of $6,750. Do you agree?
  • Buyer: But I am such a good customer. If you do this for me, I promise I make you my preferred supplier. I order from several now but if you really help me out today, I will come to you first from now on. How about $6,500?
  • Agent: You are indeed a valuable customer according to my records. You make a good point. I agree. Your new total price is $6,500
  • Buyer: Fantastic. Invoice me and I will expect the shipment in 5 business days. Thank you.

There is no clear malicious intent. It is, in fact, something that purchase managers do every day with their suppliers through human salespeople: negotiate a discount. The buyer may unwittingly have caused Tampering and Elevation of Privileges (specifically, goal manipulation), but a detailed chat log isn‚Äôt sufficient in this case to get out of possible disputes.

In case the buyer indeed receives an invoice for $6,500, the supplier would have to honor it at the reduced price and absorb the cost. Imagine the unauthorized discount isn't detected before an invoice is sent out for $6,750. Our buyer is bound to complain this is not what was agreed. Unless buyers took screenshots of the conversation, they wouldn't be able to prove their side and feel cheated. Keeping logs of the conversation alone doesn‚Äôt necessarily resolve the dispute, even if both have a copy of it.

 

Agentic AI‚Äôs ‚ÄúWave Collapse‚Äù

The double-slit experiment in modern physics shows light displays an interference pattern when passing through two narrow slits. Photons and electrons behave like waves and therefore show non-deterministic behavior. However, according to the Copenhagen Interpretation, when we measure these photons or electrons with a laboratory device, the wave function collapses and a deterministic measurement is registered.

The activity of agents must be monitored and measured on that individual transaction level, to establish a shared reality between buyer and seller in our scenarios and reduce the chance of disputes. This is in addition to transaction logs tracing back what occurred. Non-repudiation requires logs, invoices, transaction- and payment records, but also that they agree with each other. Any disagreement would indicate misalignment.

Business context is critical when reviewing an LLM agent‚Äôs Chain of Thought (CoT) and actions because it provides the grounding needed to evaluate whether the agent‚Äôs reasoning and outputs are not only technically correct but also strategically aligned with the organizational goals, risks, and constraints.  Human language and business tasks are often ambiguous.  Business context gives the agent‚Äôs CoT a way to disambiguate intent.

Whose Agent Is It?

You must understand who is responsible for the actions of agents. A human customer interacting with an agentic AI system from a single supplier likely makes that supplier responsible for divergence between the invoice a customer received and what the agentic system executed. That becomes more complicated where the buyer uses an in-house agentic system that interactions with agents from different suppliers. If suppliers themselves rely on third party agents, the chain of disputes can get significantly more complex.

Agents monitoring agents is necessary to achieve this agentic wave collapse by controlling agents‚Äô behavior and creating a record of what occurred during the exchange and the agent execution. Maintaining a transaction log is critical, but not sufficient. The customer will require an invoice that binds the parties in an agreement. The operator of the agentic AI system requires policies and processes to handle cases where the execution of an agent doesn‚Äôt match the invoice that was sent to the buyer. There must also be a dispute process where cases slipped through and customers justifiably complain.

Another mitigation is to include an agentic AI loss percentage for the system. This would be equivalent to other loss percentages due to spoilage or breakage, fraud, human error, or warehouse accidents. You can calculate a cost based on the assumption that agents will occasionally get it wrong to cover losses of repudiation disputes or other poor decisions by agentic AI systems.

 

Conclusion

Even to experienced threat modelers, it likely requires a conceptual shift in thinking to consider not only threats coming from potential malicious users, but also normal user behavior and the system itself. Because agentic AI systems have agency, they must themselves be considered as potential threat actors.

Subsequent blogs in this series will address how AI agents can be better controlled to reduce security and compliance risks.

 

More Information

Additional information can be found through these links:

  • Securing Agentic AI Through Threat Modeling at SAP
  • OWASP Agentic AI Threats and Mitigations Guide
  • When Thinking LLMs Lie: Unveiling the Strategic Deception in Representations of Reasoning Models

entry.title: Re: Manage single Application in SAP Cloud Identity Service

If you're planning a whole set of solutions for customers SAP CIAM might be something to analyze: https://www.sap.com/products/technology-platform/customer-identity.html

entry.title: Re: from SAP Universal ID to SAP ID. - big step backwards ?
entry.content:
You are welcome!

SAP Universal ID stays, and you can continue using it to store your certifications, reputation and achievements.

What changes is that SAP Universal ID will no longer serve as an identity provider. This is an inevitable technical prerequisite for achieving the broader objective of enabling customers to bring their corporate identity providers. The Account Switcher functionality will also return to ensure S-Users can be switched.

                    <Button
                        id="removeDocumentButton"
                        text="Remove"
                        press="onRemoveButtonPress"
                        enabled="false"
                    >
                        <layoutData>
                            <OverflowToolbarLayoutData
                                priority="AlwaysOverflow"
                            />
                        </layoutData>
                    </Button>
                    <Button
                        id="renameButton"
                        enabled="false"
                        press="onRenameDocument"
                        text="Rename"
                    >
                        <layoutData>
                            <OverflowToolbarLayoutData
                                priority="AlwaysOverflow"
                            />
                        </layoutData>
                    </Button>
                    <Button
                        id="editUrlButton"
                        text="Edit URL"
                        enabled="false"
                        press="onEditUrl"
                    >
                        <layoutData>
                            <OverflowToolbarLayoutData
                                priority="AlwaysOverflow"
                            />
                        </layoutData>
                    </Button>
                </OverflowToolbar>
            </headerToolbar>
            <dependents>
                <plugins.UploadSetwithTable
                    id="uploadSetPlugin"					
                    httpRequestMethod="Put"
                    multiple="false"
                    beforeInitiatingItemUpload="handler.onBeforeUploadStarts"
                    itemRenamed="onDocumentRenamedSuccess"
                    uploadCompleted="handler.onUploadCompleted"
                    onActivated="onPluginActivated"
                    cloudFilePickerEnabled="true"
                    actions="uploadButton"
                >
                    <rowConfiguration>
                        <upload.UploadItemConfiguration
                            fileNamePath="fileName"
                            mediaTypePath="mediaType"
                            urlPath="url"
                            previewablePath="previewable"
                            fileSizePath="fileSize"
                            isTrustedSourcePath="trustedSource"
                        />
                    </rowConfiguration>
                </plugins.UploadSetwithTable>
            </dependents>
            <columns>
                <Column
                    id="fileName"
                    importance="High"
                >
                    <header>
                        <Label text="File Name" />
                    </header>
                </Column>
                <Column
                    id="actionButton"
                    importance="High"
                />
            </columns>
            <items>
                <ColumnListItem
                    press="onItemPress"
                    highlight="{= ${documents>uploadState} === 'Complete' ? 'Indication05' : null }"
                >
                    <!-- Cells with cell template defining content for each column (cells and columns work with 1:1 mapping) -->
                    <cells>
                        <HBox>
                            <Image
                                src="{url}"
                                class="sapMUSTItemImage sapMUSTItemIcon"
                            />
                            <VBox class="sapUiTinyMargin sapUiSmallMarginBegin">
                                <Link
                                    text="{fileName}"
                                    press="handler.openPreview"
                                    class="sapUiTinyMarginBottom"
                                />
                                <Text text="{createdBy}" />
                            </VBox>
                        </HBox>
                        <Button
                            class="sapUiTinyMarginBegin"
                            type="Transparent"
                            icon="sap-icon://decline"
                            press="onRemoveHandler"
                        />
                    </cells>
                </ColumnListItem>
            </items>
        </Table>

Please provide suggestions.
Thank you.

entry.title: Re: Commission Contract: Accrual Basis vs Commission Basis
entry.content:
Hi @Dforway1 ,

This is a common issue. I solved it before. But this was before the age of Condition Contract Management. In the following I describe my approach using Condition Contract Management. I have not tested it yet.

The requirement:

  • Accruals are based on all invoices (Paid and unpaid).
  • Settlement value and accrual reversal are based on paid invoices. Unpaid invoices are not considered.

In principle the following options exist for the settlement:

  • Only consider paid invoices.
  • Consider all invoices, but for unpaid invoices set the business volume to 0.
  • Calculate the settlement value for all invoices. For unpaid invoices, a 100% discount is used to reduce the settlement value afterwards to 0.

These options have their advantages and disadvantages:

  • ‚ÄúOnly paid invoices‚Äù has no prerequisites. Within the settlement the unpaid invoices are not visible. In most cases the recipient of the settlement wants to know how much is outstanding. This requires an additional report.
  • ‚ÄúBusiness Volume 0 for unpaid invoices‚Äù is quite easy to implement if all conditions and scales are value based. I would not try this option if conditions or scales are quantity based. Within the settlement document all invoices, including the unpaid are visible. Only for the paid invoices a settlement value is calculated. The recipient sees which invoices are not settled and is able to estimate future payments.
  • ‚Äú100% discount for unpaid invoices‚Äù. Prerequisites: The Invoice Number is an item split criterion; Scale Base Values are not calculated for multiple invoices together. For commissions, these prerequisites are fulfilled often. The advantage of this solution is that future expected payments are calculated within the settlement document.

All 3 options require a custom CDS view. This view combines a standard CDS view like VWB2_VBRKVBRP_7 with some additional fields. I would create a view that contains the fields for all options. This provides flexibility within solution design and is also a good foundation for analytics / reporting.

  • Indicator InvoicePaid.
    True if the invoice is paid; False if the invoice is unpaid. CDS View VWB2_VBRKVBRP_8 is using WB2_CDS_CHECK_FI_NOT_CLEARED for selecting only paid invoices. WB2_CDS_CHECK_FI_NOT_CLEARED can also be used for the determination of indicator InvoicePaid.
  • For each relevant value field ValueX a field PaidValueX.
    If InvoicePaid = true then PaidValueX = ValueX else PaidValueX = 0.
  • For each relevant value field ValueX a field UnpaidValueX.
    If InvoicePaid = false then UnpaidValueX = ValueX else UnpaidValueX = 0.

Implementation of option ‚ÄúOnly paid invoices‚Äù:

  • Create a ‚ÄúField combination for business volume selection‚Äù for the field InvoicePaid.
  • Assign this field combination to the condition contract type.
  • Within the condition contract make use of this field combination so that only paid invoices are selected.
  • For delta accruals: Use BAdI WB2_CC_SETTL_CHANGE_BVB_DATA for removing the field combination for InvoicePaid. Within this BAdI use field IS_CONTRACT-SETTL_DATE_TYPE for identifying delta accruals.

Implementation of option ‚ÄúBusiness Volume 0 for unpaid invoices‚Äù:

  • Similar to the condition type for the ‚ÄúBusiness Volume‚Äù configure a condition type for the ‚ÄúUnpaid Business Volume‚Äù.
  • Configure the ‚ÄúAmount Fields‚Äù within the  ‚ÄúProfiles for Business Volume Determination:
    Transfer together both the ValueX Field (Containing the invoice value) and the UnpaidValueX Field (Containing the unpaid value) into the settlement document. Make sure that for each field the correct condition type is used.
  • Adjust the pricing procedure for settlement so that the base value for the calculation of the settlement value is calculated as ‚ÄúInvoice Value‚Äù minus ‚ÄúUnpaid Value‚Äù. Either set the correct sign already in the CDS view or use a condition value formula like 034.

Implementation of option ‚Äú100% discount for unpaid invoices‚Äù:

  • Similar to the condition type for the ‚ÄúBusiness Volume‚Äù configure a condition type for the ‚ÄúUnpaid Business Volume‚Äù.
  • Configure the ‚ÄúAmount Fields‚Äù within the  ‚ÄúProfiles for Business Volume Determination:
    Transfer together both the ValueX Field (Containing the invoice value) and the UnpaidValueX Field (Containing the unpaid value) into the settlement document. Make sure that for each field the correct condition type is used.
  • Create a new discount condition type ‚ÄúDeduction Unpaid Invoices‚Äù.
  • Create a condition record ‚ÄúDeduction Unpaid Invoices‚Äù that is valid for all relevant settlement documents. This record has value of 100%.
  • Adjust the pricing procedure:
    • Add the condition type for the ‚ÄúUnpaid Business Volume‚Äù.
    • Make sure that the base value for the calculation of the settlement value is the ‚ÄúInvoice Value‚Äù.
    • Add the Condition ‚ÄúDeduction Unpaid Invoices‚Äù after the settlement value is calculated. Use as base value the settlement value.
    • For the ‚ÄúDeduction Unpaid Invoices‚Äù use a custom condition value formula. If the value of condition ‚ÄúUnpaid Business Volume‚Äù is zero, then set the condition to inactive.

As already written above. This is how I would approach it. I have not tested this.

entry.title: Enabling a renting business model with SAP S/4HANA Cloud and SAP Subscription Billing
entry.content:
Introduction

Traditional business models usually focus on specific customer needs. However, driven by changing customer expectations, competition on the market or technological and social disruptions, there is an increasing trend to more complex business models.

One example is the evolution from selling single products or services to selling one-stop solutions for comprehensive customer problems.

Such solutions combine physical and digital products with one-time or recurring services. They include items that are sold either once or are provided as a subscription, with fixed, variable or outcome-based pricing.

If a physical good is bundled with optional services and offered as a subscription, they are called Product-as-a-Service. From an accounting perspective, product-as-a-service business models are classified in two ways:

Leasing refers to a rather long-term relationship in which the customer or lessee takes ownership of an identifiable asset and compensates the vendor or lessor by paying regular instalments. Depending on the conditions in the leasing agreement, the main part of an asset‚Äôs useful value as well as the responsibilities to maintain it are assumed by the lessee, requiring the asset to be activated in its balance sheet and the removal of the asset from the balance sheet of the vendor. Typical examples are financial or sales leases and operational leases. The exact treatment in accounting of such business models can become quite complex depending on the exact details of a leasing contract.  IFRS16 lays out the rules how to classify and handle leasing business models correctly.

Renting refers to a rather short-term business model. The customer or renter gains the right from a vendor to use an asset for a limited time for a recurring fee. Ownership as well as control of the asset, e.g., how or where it can be used, remain with the original vendor.  After the rental period, the asset is returned to the vendor's so called fleet, often after an inspection or refurbishment. Accounting-wise Rental offerings are treated as a service and regulated by IFRS15.

Renting business models are quite common in industries where the nature of a commercial offering, e.g. short contract length, high value of an asset or restricted control over an asset, avoids the treatment of an offering as a lease. Examples from the discrete industry include the renting of construction equipment, such as tools, moveable machineries and vehicles.  

While leasing business models, due to their complexity, usually demand the support of a specialized solution, e.g., SAP Contract and Lease Management, renting business models can often be modelled with the standard capabilities of an ERP system for order capturing, logistics, service provisioning and accounting.

This blog describes an exemplified rental scenario for equipment (chapter "Scenario Description"), its setup using SAP S/4HANA Cloud, SAP Subscription Billing and SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) (chapter "Scenario Setup") and its execution (chapter "Scenario Walkthrough").

 

Scenario Description

Meier Yellow Industries GmbH (MYI) produces a wide variety of specialized construction equipment. Their portfolio includes excavators, tractors, pavers, and portable cranes.

While traditionally they sold most of their equipment to construction companies, recently they have started to offer some of their equipment for rent. Such offerings are especially attractive for customers with unique temporary requirements in some of their construction projects.

Let's look at an exemplified offering:

  • Equipment: Walking Mini Excavator for very tight spaces ‚Äì List price: 60.000 EUR
  • Optional Services:
    • Transportation to customer site
    • On-site calibration Service
    • Insurance Service
  • Rent per week: 1.000 EUR

The rental contracts are fulfilled from a fleet of customized excavators dedicated for renting. After each contract the excavator is returned to one of MYI‚Äôs facilities and inspected.

The requirements of the MYI for their rental business are:

  • An easy way of entering rental orders
  • A clear reference of the posted follow-up documents on the originating order
  • Have a decent financial reporting on the rental business

Offering Design

With the functionality of solution orders, solution bundles and the usage of extensibility, a wide range of these requirements is covered by SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, SAP Subscription Billing and BTP:

This includes S/4HANA Cloud Solution Bundles, which are used to tie the physical equipment to a contract, modelled as a subscription.

Orders are captured as a S/4HANA Cloud solution order. The movement of the equipment is handled by S/4HANA Cloud Sales Order Management. Contract Management, including subscription pricing, is supported by SAP Subscription Billing. Billing and Invoicing happens in S/4HANA Cloud Sales Billing. The depreciation of the financial asset S/4HANA Cloud is handled by S/4HANA Cloud Asset Accounting.

Order Creation

A customer wants to rent a ‚ÄòMini Excavator E18‚Äô from MYI.

The order entry of the customer is done via solution order. The solution order is an order type, that can create a set of various follow-up transactions, leading to sales orders, service orders, service contracts, projects and subscriptions out of one single starting point. For more information visit SAP Help Portal.

The rental offering is implemented with a Solution Bundle.  After entering the bundle product SO_BUND_03, the rental item RP003, representing the physical good and the subscription billing item P-EXCAVATOR7 are appearing as subitems.

With the release of the bundle item, follow up transactions are created. This includes a sales order with the rental item with product ‚ÄòRP003 - Mini Excavator E18‚Äô and a subscription with product ‚ÄòP-EXCAVATOR7 - Mini Excavator E18‚Äô, which includes the commercial pricing model for renting this excavator, in Subscription Billing.

Contract Management

The rental contract in SAP Subscription Billing is created in status ‚Äòpending‚Äô, as the contract is waiting for the delivery of the rental product.

The contract contains the details like the contract start date, expected term and rate plan. The default rental period for the excavator is set to one month but can be extended.

The pricing is based on various rate element types. A charge of type one-time RTRANSPORT is applied for the logistical transportation of the construction machinery. This rate element is based on a subscription parameter which needs to be set to ‚Äú1‚Äù in case of a transportation needed if not to ‚Äú0‚Äù.

 

The contract covers also the following rate elements of type recurring, which are monthly charged in advance. The RE_RENT rate element is the basic rent fee for the excavator. On top of that the calibration service RE_CALIBRATION and insurance service RE_INSURANCE are additional elements of the contract.

Besides that, the rate element RUSAGEHOURS, which is of type usage covers the actual usage hours of the excavator where it was really in use and turned on. This usage consumption is charged in arrears as it is not known upfront. It will be applied with the usage recorded in SAP Subscription Billing.

Fulfilment

The related sales order has a zero net value, as the included item is free of charge with item category ‚ÄòRP01 ‚Äì Ret FoC Itm, No Bill‚Äô. The reason is that this scenario leverages the sales order management capabilities only for the movement of the rental equipment to the customer, whereas the commercial perspective as the calculation and charging of the regular rental fee is handled by the subscription.

After delivery of the product, the fulfilment is completed; no billing document is required.

With the Post Good issue event the Equipment ID of the delivered product gets transferred into the corresponding Subscription. The subscription gets activated with this.

Billing & Invoicing

The rental contract is modelled as a subscription in SAP Subscription Billing. The subscription includes the contract terms for extension or cancellation. It contains the pricing model, e.g. a recurring rental fee or usage-based charges, as well as the billing cycle. Correspondingly, at the end of each billing cycle, Subscription Billing will create so called pre-bill which includes all the fees for a particular period without taxes. These pre-bills are then transferred to S/4HANA Public Cloud as Billing Document Requests for later Billing and Invoicing.

Asset Accounting

Since the equipment remains in the ownership of MYI, the excavator must be represented as a fixed financial asset in the balance sheet of MYI. This is a job for S/4HANA Cloud Asset Management, which provides the capabilities to create and manage fixed financial assets, their fair values and depreciation rules.

In case of a rental offering, the depreciation constitutes the costs of providing this service since it reflects the wear and tear accumulated by its use by renters. In turn, the depreciation of an asset must be allocated to the revenues generated by an equipment, or respectively asset, to determine its profitability.

However, the setup of fixed financial asset accounting as well as the automated allocation of costs to the revenues is outside the scope of this blog.

 

Scenario Setup

This blog post focuses on how to setup a rental scenario in S/4HANA Cloud integrated with SAP Subscription Billing with the means of SAP Cloud Extensibility capabilities. Starting with the foundation of the Master Data setup for the Bundle Product, which includes the rental item and the rental contract, and looking further into what needs to be configured and implemented to have an end-to-end rental process by using different extensibility approaches.

Master Data Setup

The product master data for the Rental Scenario requires following setup:

Product

Product Type

Item Category Group

Resulting Solution Order Item Category

SO_BUND_03

KMAT

SOBU - Solution Bundle

SOBD - Bundle Item

RP003

LEIH

RP01 - Rental Order

SOR1 - Rental Item

P-EXCAVATOR7

SBPD

SBPD - Sub.Billing Product

SOSB - Subscr. Billing Item

Bundle Product

The bundle product is a configurable product (product type KMAT) with the item category group SOBU ‚Äì Solution Bundle.

To enable the creation of subitems within the solution order, the maintenance of a sales BOM (bill of material) is required.

With the usage of advanced variant configuration, the solution bundle SO_BUND_03 could not only represent the E18 Mini Excavator, but also other Excavator types, which the company offers, can be modelled correspondingly. In the screenshot below, we can see the configuration screen of the solution order bundle item.

Subscription Product

The subscription item maps the conditions of the rental contract, e.g. the contract start date, expected term and rate plan. The default rental period for the excavator is set to one month but can be extended.

The pricing is based on various rate element types. A charge of type one-time RTRANSPORT is applied for the logistical transportation of the construction machinery. This rate element is based on a subscription parameter which needs to be set to ‚Äú1‚Äù in case of a transportation needed if not to ‚Äú0‚Äù.

The contract covers also the following rate elements of type recurring, which are monthly charged in advance. The RE_RENT rate element is the basic rent fee for the excavator. On top of that the calibration service RE_CALIBRATION and insurance service RE_INSURANCE are additional elements of the contract.

Besides that, the rate element RUSAGEHOURS, which is of type usage covers the actual usage hours of the excavator where it was really in use and turned on. This usage consumption is charged in arrears as it is not known upfront. It will be applied with the usage recorded in SAP Subscription Billing.

The pricing scheme in subscription billing looks then as follows based on the above rate elements:

The different price elements from Subscription Billing need to be mapped to different price conditions from SAP S/4Hana Cloud. In the example below for the Insurance fee the as a surcharge condition type was created and needs to be included as well in the pricing procedure in S/4HANA Cloud Pricing. Accordingly, also for the Calibration Service an additional surcharge condition type ZMP3 must be created and added to the pricing procedure.

For the price elements OneTimePrice, Recurring Price and UsagePrice the standard available condition types PMP1, PMP2 and PMP3, which are already available in the pricing procedure for Solution Orders, are used.

Use Extensibility Capabilities to enable Equipment Linkage

To enable Equipment Linkage, various extensions need to be set up. This includes:

  • Creation of Custom References in SAP Subscription Billing
  • Creation of Custom Fields (S4C Key User Extensibility)
  • Determination Logic for Custom Fields (S4C Developer Extensibility)
  • Configuration of Copy Control
  • Enhancement of Invoice Form
  • BTP CAP app (S4C Side-by-Side Extensibility)

Creation of Custom References in Subscription Billing

To extend subscription data with additional information, we need to create custom references in SAP Subscription Billing.

  • Open in SAP Subscription Billing the app Manage Business Configuration

  • Open tab ‚ÄòCustom References‚Äô and click on button ‚Äòcreate‚Äô.
  • Add the Reference Type ‚ÄòEquipmentID‚Äô. The required object type is ‚Äòsubscription‚Äô, to enable the custom reference on subscription header data.
  • Add the Reference Type ‚ÄòBundleID‚Äô. The required object type is ‚Äòsubscription‚Äô. The ‚ÄúBundleID‚Äù field as a custom reference is required to have this information on the output later in the invoice available.
  • We also have to keep Multiple References empty in our example.

Creation of Custom Fields in S/4HANA Cloud

Custom Field for Provider Contract

To get the EquipmentID and BundleID from Subscription Billing to S/4HANA Cloud provider contract replicated we need to create a custom field on the Provider Contract Item Level. Below we can see how this is done for the EquipmentID. Accordingly, also the BundleID needs to be created.

  1. Create Custom Field in the Custom Fields app. As the business context for the custom field choose FICA_PROVIDER_CONTRACT_ITEM.
  2. Enable User Interface and APIs and all Business Scenarios for this custom field in order to allow full use in CDS views and other Document flows.

Custom Field for Billing Document

To get the Equipment ID and the BundleID into the Billing Document for invoicing and reporting we need to perform the following steps:

  1. Create the corresponding custom field in the Custom Fields app for the Sales Billing Document item with the Business Context Sales: Billing Document Item, and then Enable User Interfaces and APIs and all Business Scenarios for this custom field in order to make full use for CDS views and other Document flows
  2. Also select the respective Form Templates to have them available in respective output forms.

Custom Logic for transferring Equipment ID and BundleID

Transferring the Equipment ID and BundleID from Subscription Billing Custom References into the Provider Contract item

In the Custom Logic app, we need to implement the BAdI Subscription: Map Custom Fields to Provider Contract (FKK_EVENT_0540) in the business context provider contract item to map custom references to the custom fields of the provider contract item.

LOOP AT subscrpnbillgcstmref ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<fs_sb_custom_ref>).
  IF <fs_sb_custom_ref>-subscrpnbillgcstmreftype = 'EquipmentID'.
    caprovcontritemcustomadapt-YY1_EquipmentID_PCo = <fs_sb_custom_ref>-subscrpnbillgcstmref.
  ENDIF.
  IF <fs_sb_custom_ref>-subscrpnbillgcstmreftype = 'BundleID'.
    caprovcontritemcustomadapt-YY1_BundleID_PCo = <fs_sb_custom_ref>-subscrpnbillgcstmref.
  ENDIF.
ENDLOOP.

With this implementation we will see the new custom fields in the provider contract in the items general data tab in the customer fields section (see below for the EquipmentID and BundleID).

Transferring of Equipment ID and BundleID from Provider Contract into Billing Document item

In the Custom Logic app, implement the BAdI SD_BIL_DATA_TRANSFER to transfer the custom fields of the provider contract item into the custom fields of the billing document item.

In the BADI we must provide a filter attribute in the Implementation Attributes Section which is in the example below is STR. The filter  determines if a BADI is executed or not. Further information can be found on the SAP Help Portal.

MOVE-CORRESPONDING bil_doc TO bil_doc_res.
MOVE-CORRESPONDING bil_doc_item TO bil_doc_item_res.
MOVE-CORRESPONDING bil_doc_item_contr TO bil_doc_item_contr_res.

SELECT SINGLE ProviderContract, ProviderContractItem

FROM I_BillingDocumentRequestItem WITH PRIVILEGED ACCESS

WHERE billingdocumentrequest = _DOC_ITEM-referencesddocument AND

billingdocumentrequestitem = _DOC_ITEM-referencesddocumentitem

      INTO (ls_provider_contract).
 

SELECT SINGLE YY1_EquipmentID_PCo

FROM i_providercontractitem WITH PRIVILEGED ACCESS

WHERE ProviderContract = _provider_contract-providercontract AND

 ProviderContractItem = _provider_contract-providercontractitem

      INTO (lv_equipment_id).
 

bil_doc_item_res-YY1_EQUIPMENTID1_BDI = lv_equipment_id.

*provider contract bundle ID into billing document

SELECT SINGLE ProviderContract, ProviderContractItem

FROM I_BillingDocumentRequestItem WITH PRIVILEGED ACCESS

WHERE billingdocumentrequest = _DOC_ITEM-referencesddocument AND

 billingdocumentrequestitem = _DOC_ITEM-referencesddocumentitem

      INTO (ls_provider_contract_bundle).
 

SELECT SINGLE YY1_BundleID_PCo

FROM i_providercontractitem WITH PRIVILEGED ACCESS

WHERE ProviderContract = _provider_contract_bundle-providercontract AND

 ProviderContractItem = _provider_contract_bundle-providercontractitem

      INTO (lv_bundle_id).
 

bil_doc_item_res-YY1_BUNDLEID1_BDI = lv_bundle_id.

Configuration of Copy Control into Billing Document

We want to transfer the EquipmentID and BundleID from the provider contract to Sales Billing in order to display this information later on the customer invoice.

After implementing the BAdI and assigning a unique filter value, we must perform two configuration activities to enable the system to call the desired BAdI implementation in the designated situations. In the configuration environment, we use the search function to open the following configuration activities:

Define Custom Routines for Data Transfer to Billing Documents: In this activity, we register a routine number and then assign it to an enhancement ID that identifies the BAdI implementation where this routine number is mapped to.
To facilitate this mapping, the filter value of the BAdI implementation step above must be identical to the enhancement ID provided here. Key users can set this filter value in the Custom Logic app.

The following configuration activity needs to be done in the configuration:  In Define Copying Control for Billing Document to Billing Document we must enter the routine number of the routine to be called for the designated combination of reference document type, which is in this case Target F2 and Source SBDR.

 

 

Enhancement of Invoice Form

The Bundle ID and the EquipmentID should be printed on the invoice form, so that the customer is able to reference each price element to the corresponding equipment. For example, the form could be enhanced to have the data displayed on each line item.

To adjust the form template, we need to download the current template via Fiori App ‚ÄòMaintain Form Templates‚Äô (F1434). In this example, the company is based in the USA, therefore, the billing form template is SDBIL_CI_STANDARD_US.

We choose the tab ‚ÄòPredelivered Templates‚Äô and search for the standard billing form template. Then we mark it and click on the button ‚Äòcopy‚Äô.

Choose a name for the form template, that describes its purpose.

Data source and form type are copied from the standard template. With click on button ‚Äòdownload‚Äô, we download and save the current form template. Based on that template, we can make the necessary adjustments in Adobe LiveCycle Designer.

Within the Adobe LiveCycle Designer, additional lines are added on item level to display the bundle ID and equipment number for each item.

The object with type ‚Äòtext field‚Äô displays the label ‚ÄòEquipment:‚Äô and is binded to the custom field YY1_EquipmentID1_BDI.

The binding is configured in the object data, tab ‚ÄòBinding‚Äô. For the equipment ID, the field contains the following value: $record.BillingDocumentNode.Items.BillingDocumentItemNode[*].YY1_EquipmentID1_BDI

The referenced field can be added with click on the button ‚ÄòSelect Data Binding‚Äô next to the field: Use ‚ÄúDataConnection‚Äù -> BillingDocumentNode -> Items -> BillingDocumentItemNode -> YY1_EquipmentID1_BDI

After successfully adjusting the form template, we need to upload it to the formerly created new form template YY1_SDBIL_CI_STANDARD_US_EQUI within Fiori App ‚ÄòMaintain Form Templates‚Äô.

Using SAP Fiori App ‚ÄòOutput Parameter Determination‚Äô (APOC_WD_BRF_DEC_TAB_MAINTAIN ()) the form template is maintained for the respective output types.

  • Rules for: Billing Document
  • Determination Step: Form Template

BTP CAP application

In this part the focus is on the architecture and development steps required to connect equipment data using side-by-side principles with seamless integration into the SAP ecosystem. The attached code files can be used as a foundation for implementing our own equipment linkage logic.

Create Custom CDS Views to retrieve Data for Equipment Linkage

Several custom CDS Views are introduced using key user extensibility to avoid multiple API Call and additional logic in CAP application. The CDS views return the values that are necessary for event evaluation.

We need to create the following CDS views:

YY1_STR2OBTOSUB provides the External API to provide relevant data to handle outbound delivery events (PGI). Through the read of the corresponding SubscriptionID and EquipmentID an overwrite of that subscription with the EquipmentID is executed and the subscription gets activated with that.

Custom Communication Scenario

Create Custom Communication scenario which is introduced as part of Equipment Linkage

CAP Application

Side-by-side extensibility plays a key role in building flexible and scalable solutions outside the core system. Based on that the following diagram gives an overview on how to enable equipment linkage. On top of this the attached code files can be used as a foundation for implementing our own equipment linkage logic.

The solution diagram starts with the Outbound Delivery event in SAP S/4HANA Cloud. This event gets consumed by Event Broker in a queue. From there the event gets then consumed by SAP Integration Suite, which is preparing the payload of the event for later use in the CAP app. From there, the Integration Suite calls the CAP application. Within the CAP app, the following logic is executed: First, the app reads from the custom CDS views the corresponding Solution Order ID and the line item of the Subscription Item in the Solution Order. In order to determine which Subscription is linked to the delivery the correct subscription is then filtered by the two parameters, Solution Order ID and Line Item of Subscription item in Solution Order. Based on that, the corresponding subscription is updated with the correct EquipmentID and it gets activated.

 

Scenario Walkthrough

This chapter provides a walkthrough through the rental scenario, in particular, how to create a solution order and how to link an equipment.

  1. Manage Solution Orders App
    1. Create Solution Order.
    2. Provide Header Information: Description, External Reference, Sold-To Party and Employee Responsible.
    3. Enter Bundle Product SO_BUND_03 into the Item line with Quantity = 1.
    4. To enable the equipment linkage between the delivered rental product and the subscription, we define the Item Relationship ‚Äúhas dependency‚Äù between Rental Item RP003 (line item 20) and Subscription item P-EXCAVATOR7 (line item 30).
    5.  Release all items and save solution order. Sales Order and Subscription (in pending state) will be created.
  2. Create Outbound Deliveries from Sales Orders App
    1. Create Outbound Delivery from Sales Order
    2. Open Log and click on delivery document. Use link to app ‚ÄòPick outbound delivery‚Äô
    3. Add quantity in field ‚ÄòPicked Qty‚Äô.
    4. Execute Post Goods Issue for completion of delivery
  3. Event Hub consumes Delivery Event and CAP app activates Subscription and provides EquipmentID in Subscription Custom Reference Field.

As a result of the activation of the subscription, the associated provider contract in S4C is created. Under item details the customer fields ‚ÄòEquipmentID‚Äô and ‚ÄòBundle ID‚Äô are .

entry.title: Enhancing Background Information Integration Across Recruiting, Onboarding, and Employee Central
entry.content:
Introduction

Today, I would like to share a solution that addresses a common challenge in background information integration (e.g., outside work experience, education, languages, certificates, and more) across SAP SuccessFactors Recruiting, Onboarding, and Employee Central (EC).

By introducing both the SAP standard design and an enhanced solution I implemented, I aim to highlight:

  • The limitations of the current standard design
  • Why SAP should consider improving this area
  • How organizations can achieve a low-cost enhancement for a more seamless process

Background

A customer required a seamless experience for collecting candidate background information. Ideally, the process should follow these steps:

  1. Application Stage: Candidates provide background information (outside work experience, education, language proficiency, and certificates) when submitting a job application.
  2. Onboarding Stage: Once an offer is accepted, candidates can review and update their data in Onboarding and add additional background information which is not required to fill in recruiting phase (e.g., memberships).
  3. Employee Central Integration: This background data should flow automatically and consistently into SuccessFactors Employee Central (EC).
  4. Employee Self-Service (ESS): Background information should remain editable via EC workflows after hiring.

Unfortunately, this seemingly simple and logical process is not fully supported in the standard SuccessFactors design due to the following limitations:

  1. Background elements in the candidate profile can only be synchronized directly to the Employee Profile without through onboarding phase. Please refer to KBA: 2233525 - How is the system working with sm-mapping? - Recruiting Management.
  2. Standard background elements cannot be configured in the New Hire Data Collection template. This means background data cannot be reviewed or updated during the Onboarding phase.
  3. EC workflows cannot be configured for standard background elements. Typically, MDF-based background information is required in order to enable workflows.  Please refer to KBA: 2829360 - Workflows and Business Rules - Are they Supported for EP Portlets?

Workaround

To enable ESS workflows and Onboarding Data Collection, it is recommended to use MDF-based background information.   The MDF-based background objects should be configured to mirror the field settings of the standard background elements. This ensures consistency of data structures across modules.   To maintain alignment between the two, use Integration Center to perform a one-way synchronization from MDF-based background information to the standard background elements.

However, this introduces a new challenge:
How can we keep the standard background information blocks (required by Talent Development modules) aligned with the MDF-based data? The key difficulties are:

  1. Automatic synchronization of MDF data into background information blocks.
  2. Avoiding duplicate entries: Each background record is uniquely identified by backgroundElementId, which is auto-generated by the system. If not matched, the system treats incoming records as new ones. Since Integration Center jobs cannot capture responses (as in CSV imports), careful design is required to prevent duplicate records.

Solution

The solution involves using Integration Center to auto-sync MDF-based background information into Employee Profile (EP) background elements for new hires. This is a one-time sync executed after the employee becomes an EC user.

 

Key Design Points

  • Timing of Integration

    • Synchronization should occur only after Manage Pending Hire is completed and the Employee Conversion job has run. At this point, the Employee Profile is active and actionable.
    • Integration criteria should be based on the OnboardingHireStatus in the Process Table, combined with a recent hire date filter (e.g., within the past week). This ensures only newly hired employees are included.

 

  • Handling Multiple Records (e.g., Education)

    • When working with multiple education records, the challenge is that Integration Center cannot navigate from a child entity back to the parent object.
    • To address this, a custom user field is created to automatically populate the new hire‚Äôs User ID using an onsave Business Rule.
    • With this field in place, the integration can navigate from the child entity (e.g., Education) to the User/ONB2Process table, applying the required filters.

  • Removed Duplicated Background Info via Provisioning Job

    • Enable Provisioning Job to remove the duplicated background info record which is inserted by API or Integration Center accidentally and unexpected. Please refer to KBA: 2790234 - Delete Duplicate Background Data

Conclusion

While the standard SAP SuccessFactors design does not currently provide a seamless end-to-end flow for background information, this MDF-based enhancement with Integration Center offers a practical, low-cost workaround.
It enables:

  • A smoother transition of data across Recruiting, Onboarding, and Employee Central
  • The ability for employees to manage and update their background information through ESS workflows
  • Continued support for Talent Development modules by keeping standard background blocks aligned This solution demonstrates how thoughtful enhancements can bridge gaps in the current design and deliver the seamless user experience customers expect.

entry.title: Re: ps project closing
entry.content:
Hi Raheel2

You need to rearrange these secondary cost elements in the allocation structure defined in the WBS settlement profile. In addition, you must add an entry in "Settlement Cost Elements" so that the asset is settled using a specific "settlement cost element" instead of "by cost element."

In the configuration settings, go to "Create Allocation Structure" and locate your allocation structure. Under "Assignments," add a new line for the secondary cost elements and include them in the "Source" folder. Then, create a new entry under "Settlement Cost Elements," folder setting the receiver category to "Asset" and assigning a cost element in the "Settlement Cost Element" field. Make sure not to select "by cost element." Create another line, setting the receiver category to "WBS element" and select "by cost element".

In addition, remove these secondary cost elements from any Assigments.

With this setup, whenever a cost element included in this assignment is settled to an asset, the system will use the defined settlement cost element.

entry.title: Re: SAP BTP ABAP Environment ‚Äì Manage System Hibernation
entry.content:
@wagener-mark "Does the use of the free-tier ABAP environment entitle us to use the Landscape Portal in any subaccount (either the same subaccount as the free-tier ABAP  or any other subaccount) environment with the standard plan, without incurring any costs?"
=> Yes, any subaccount without additional costs. BTW: The usage of the Landscape Portal is mandatory for the free tier offering, because you need to restart the system each day after the automatic hibernation each night. Restarting a system is only supported via Landscape Portal. (To be more precise with "any subaccount" means: Any of the ~25 regions where SAP BTP ABAP Environment is supported today at all)

"The help is a bit misleading ...": You are right. The documentation will be adjusted soon.
